questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents to OPD with an inability to focus on close objects over the previous few hours. However, she reports that she can see distant objects. On examination, she can move her eyes normally. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged in such a condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Oculomotor nerve and long ciliary nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Short ciliary nerves and ciliary ganglion

questions.correct_answer: C. Short ciliary nerves and ciliary ganglion

questions.text: During the neurological examination of a 43-year-old male patient, the corneal reflex is absent on the left side but intact on the right side. Which nerve injury can result in the loss of the corneal reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.correct_answer: A. The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.text: Which pair of structures is most likely to be compressed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm?
questions.correct_answer: C. Azygos vein and thoracic duct

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented to the physician’s clinic with a sudden onset of neck pain radiating to the forearm for the past 1 day. He had been feeling a dull pain in the left upper back since playing golf two days earlier. The physician orders an MRI that reveals a cervical nerve root mass. Which of the following might be affected if the nerve root affected was C8?

options.label: C
options.text: Adduction and Abduction of interossei muscles

questions.correct_answer: B. Flexors of wrist and fingers

An MRI of the shoulder shows a muscle tear. Which muscles are most likely to be damaged by this injury?

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is brought to the Neurology OPD with fluent speech but inability to repeat words, difficulty naming people and writing, though understanding what is told. CT brain is recommended. As the intern on duty, you suspect a lesion in which area of the brain?
Which structure connects the sternum to the scapula?
Which of the following locations do you think fibrocartilage is present?
How long does the ovum remain viable after ovulation?

A medical student is observing the contraction of skeletal muscle. He notices that each time he administers a stimulus, the muscle contracts for a short time until it relaxes. Upon increasing the frequency of the stimulus, the frequency of these contractions increases until a frequency is reached at which the muscle shows sustained contraction and does not relax. What is the underlying mechanism behind this kind of contraction?

options.label: B
options.text: Failure of Ca++ removal from the sarcoplasm

options.label: D
options.text: Increased activity of sarcoplasmic Ca++ ATPase

questions.correct_answer: B. Failure of Ca++ removal from the sarcoplasm

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete suddenly fell during his rehearsal half an hour before and presented to the emergency department. There is an increased heart rate of about 148 bpm and palpitations. The attending doctor prescribes him bed rest and some medication and writes down the Bowditch effect in diagnosis. What is true about Bowditch's effect on the heart?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in HR decreases relaxation.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in HR increases relaxation.

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in HR decreases contraction.

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in HR increases contraction.

questions.correct_answer: D. An increase in HR increases contraction.

options.text: Decreasing workload, increasing duration of exercise

questions.text: A professor is explaining the physiology of countercurrent multiplication. Countercurrent multiplication in the kidneys is the process of using energy to generate an osmotic gradient that enables you to reabsorb water from the tubular fluid and produce concentrated urine. This mechanism prevents you from producing liters and liters of dilute urine every day. It is the reason why you do not need to be continually drinking to stay hydrated. The prime driving force for this system is?

options.label: B
options.text: Reabsorption of Na + in the thick ascending limb

options.label: C
options.text: Action of ADH via aquaporin channels

questions.correct_answer: B. Reabsorption of Na + in the thick ascending limb

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with involuntary, painful muscle contractions in her hands and feet for three days, accompanied by tingling. She has a history of thyroidectomy. Lab tests reveal hypocalcemia . The described muscle activity, when voluntary, mirrors a physiological condition in which muscles achieve maximum tension without subsequent relaxation, similar to post-tetanic potentiation . Which of the following is typically implicated in facilitating this response in muscle tissue?

options.label: C
options.text: A buildup of calcium in the presynaptic terminal

questions.correct_answer: A. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ When the nerves send a weak signal to contract a muscle , the motor units in the muscle that contains the smallest muscle fibers are stimulated in preference to the larger motor units . As the signal increases in strength, larger motor units also begin to be excited .
  • ↳ Gradually, the frequency of muscle contraction also increases, and there comes the point at which a new contraction occurs before the preceding one ends. This second contraction is added partially to the firs t, increasing the total strength of the contraction . When the frequency reaches a n optimum level , the successive contractions f use, and the muscle tension reaches its peak with no relaxation observed, the action appears to be completely smooth ; this is called tetanization. A sustained muscle contraction remains in this stage for some time.
  • ↳ Post-tetanic facilitation is the neuronal phenomenon in which a neuron is more easily excited after a brief period of activity . It occurs after tetanic stimulation of the presynaptic neuron. It is due to the buildup the calcium ions in the presynaptic membrane caused by the prior neur onal activity . Subsequent neuronal impulses release neurotransmitter s more r eadily due to this pre-placed calcium from the pr evious stimulus .
  • ↳ Option A: Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  • ↳ During the depolarisation stage of the action potential , the membrane become s suddenly permeable to sodium ions. Voltage-gated sodium channels open up, allowing many positively charged sodium i ons to flow into the cell's interior . It causes the normal resting negative potential to change into a positive potential. Hence, these channels play a significant role in the depolarisation and repolarization of the nerve membrane.
  • ↳ During the depolarisation stage of the action potential , the membrane become s suddenly permeable to sodium ions. Voltage-gated sodium channels open up, allowing many positively charged sodium i ons to flow into the cell's interior . It causes the normal resting negative potential to change into a positive potential. Hence, these channels play a significant role in the depolarisation and repolarization of the nerve membrane.
  • ↳ Option B: Opening of transmitter-gated potassium channels
  • ↳ Transmitter-gated or ligand-gated potassium ion channels are activated upon binding a neurotransmitter, hormone, or second messengers to the ion channel. They are involved in fast synaptic transmission in the nervous system. The flow of ions across the membrane will either depolarize or hyperpolarization.
  • ↳ Transmitter-gated or ligand-gated potassium ion channels are activated upon binding a neurotransmitter, hormone, or second messengers to the ion channel. They are involved in fast synaptic transmission in the nervous system. The flow of ions across the membrane will either depolarize or hyperpolarization.
  • ↳ Option D: Electrotonic conduction
  • ↳ It is the passive flow of a change in electric potential along a nerve or muscle membrane. It occurs in response to insufficient stimulation to trigger an actively propagated action potential but instead generates depolarisation in a small area of the membrane.
  • ↳ It is the passive flow of a change in electric potential along a nerve or muscle membrane. It occurs in response to insufficient stimulation to trigger an actively propagated action potential but instead generates depolarisation in a small area of the membrane.

questions.text: Which statement best describes a functional role for the lateral hemispheres of the cerebellum?

options.label: A
options.text: Control and coordinate movements of the axial muscles, as well as the shoulder and hip

options.label: B
options.text: Control movements that involve distal limb musculature

options.label: C
options.text: Function with the cerebral cortex to plan, execute and coordinate movements

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulate motor neurons through their connections to the spinal cord

questions.correct_answer: C. Function with the cerebral cortex to plan, execute and coordinate movements

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the composition of the organ of Corti ?

options.label: A
options.text: A single row of inner hair cells and a single row of outer hair cells

options.label: B
options.text: 3-4 rows of each inner and outer hair cell.

options.label: C
options.text: A single row of inner hair cells and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.

options.label: D
options.text: A single row of outer hair cells and 3-4 rows of inner hair cells

questions.correct_answer: C. A single row of inner hair cells and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.

questions.text: Which of the following represents normal 'Y' descent in the JVP ?

options.label: D
options.text: Isovolumetric relaxation of the right ventricle

questions.correct_answer: C. Opening of the tricuspid valve

questions.text: What is the primary mediator of malignancy-associated hypercalcemia?
Which of the following statements regarding digestion and absorption of fat is not correct ?

options.text: The stomach secretes a lipase enzyme that plays a role in the digestion of fat.

options.label: B
options.text: Most of the lipids are digested by pancreatic lipase.

options.label: C
options.text: Bile acids emulsify lipids in the small intestine, increasing the surface area for digestion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of intractable vomiting and inability to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood analysis still shows a normal glucose level. Which of the following processes is mainly responsible for the blood glucose maintenance in this patient?

A 46-year-old woman complains of epigastric pain that is relieved after meals but worsens after 1-2 hours. Investigations suggest bacterial infection of intestinal cells, leading to the production of large amounts of ammonia (NH3) as a result of metabolic activities . This NH3 can rapidly diffuse into the intestine and the portal vein, entering the circulation. What is the probable cause for the absorption of NH3 in this scenario?

options.label: B
options.text: Conversion of NH 3 to ammonium ion in the blood

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased concentration of bicarbonate in the blood

questions.correct_answer: B. Conversion of NH 3 to ammonium ion in the blood

questions.text: In Hyperhemolytic conditions or chronic hemolysis, hemoglobin is oxidatively degraded to release free heme from ferric hemoglobin. This free heme can accelerate tissue damage by promoting peroxidative reactions and activation of inflammatory cascades. Which of the following protein binds to free heme to inhibit these effects.

A researcher is studying the process of gene expression in different cells of the body. His finding points out that although all the cells of the body have the same genetic information in their nucleus the genetic material is selectively expressed depending on the specific type and function of the cell in the tissue. The figure below shows the technique used by the researcher for this purpose. Which of the following genetic techniques is shown in the figure?

(Chromatin Immuno Precipitation)

(Gene Silencing technique)

technique for detecting Protein DNA interaction

and Histone modifications

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints. Blood glutamine was found to be increased . Also, uracil levels were raised . what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D

questions.text: Which DNA repair mechanism is employed by the CRISPR/Cas9 technology , allowing researchers to edit specific parts of the genome selectively?

A 60-year-old male patient presents with episodes of pain, especially in the hands and feet, a decreased ability to sweat (hypohidrosis), clusters of small, dark red spots on the skin called angiokeratomas, corneal opacity (cloudiness of eyes), episodes of seizures in the recent past. On histopathology examination and urine examination following image was obtained : Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the above-mentioned patient?

A 5-month-old boy was hospitalized after experiencing a seizure, lethargy and dehydration. The infant had reduced food intake due to a stomach infection, and the blood glucose level upon admission was 28 mg/dl. Urine analysis revealed the absence of ketone bodies but the presence of various dicarboxylic acids . What could be the underlying cause of fasting hypoglycemia in this case ?

options.label: A
options.text: Defect in converting acetyl CoA to glucose

options.label: B
options.text: High production of ATP and NADH

options.label: C
options.text: Increased conversion of acetyl CoA to acetoacetate

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient is diagnosed with Alport syndrome . Further testing would reveal a defect in which of the following proteins ?

A 15-day-old baby is brought to the clinic by his mother with the complaint of frequent vomiting. He has recently started feeding on breast milk . An appropriate diagnosis is made, and the patient is discharged after the resolution of the symptoms. A few days later, the baby presents to the clinic again with jaundice. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Ocular examination shows the following findings: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?

A 10-month-old boy visits the clinic accompanied by his parents with a history of failure to thrive. Physical examination shows jaundice and splenomegaly. A CBC shows a microcytic, hypochromic anaemia (haemoglobin - 7.3 g/dL). Fetal haemoglobin accounts for most of the haemoglobin. A peripheral blood film is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?

A 7 Yr old girl child with a known case of Non-Hodgkins lymphoma on Cyclophosphamide now presents with sudden onset fever and petechiae. Bone marrow examination revealed Hypercellular Lymphoblastic cells. Which of the following Lymphoid malignancy described here arise from thymic cells?

A 48-year-old alcoholic man comes in with a 6-day history of productive cough and fever. The temperature is 38.7°C (103°F), the heart rate is 32 beats per minute, and the blood pressure is 126/86 mm Hg. The patient's cough worsens, and he starts coughing up a lot of foul-smelling sputum. An X-ray of the chest reveals an infiltrate in the right upper and middle lobes. A CBC reveals leukocytosis (WBC = 38,000/mL), with 80% of neutrophils being slightly immature and toxic granulation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of leukocyte alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following best describes the hematologic condition of this patient?

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented to medical OPD with low-grade fever, fatigue and unexplained weight loss for the last six months. On examination, an enlarged supraclavicular lymph node was palpated. The image depicts the histology of her lymph node biopsy. The tumour cells express B cell antigens and are Epstein-Barr virus-positive (EBV). The patient is HIV positive and is on antiviral medication. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old lady with no known co-morbid presented to the hospital with complaints of spontaneous vaginal bleeding. She gets symptomatic treatment. She suffers from a tonic-clonic seizure in the next 24 hours. She is febrile, jaundiced , and has extensive purpura on physical examination. A haemoglobin of 5.3 g/dL with 8% reticulocytes, a platelet count of 10,000/mL, and a BUN of 48 mg/dL were found in the lab. A peripheral blood smear is also advised. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 10-day-old infant presents with a complaint of projectile vomiting. His mother states that the infant will actively drink his milk, but he forcefully vomits after each feeding. The infant shows signs of failure to thrive, with weight loss, dehydration, and lethargy. Physical examination reveals a firm, nontender, mobile, "olive-shaped" epigastric mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and painful, stiff joints for one month. She has no significant medical or surgical history. Physical examination reveals signs of pallor and jaundice. Her vitals are within normal limits. Investigation findings include anaemia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia with increased reticulocyte count. Direct Coombs test is positive for C3d. The peripheral blood film is shown below. What is the most likely cause of this pathology?

A 6-year-old boy presented with swelling of his left parotid gland and pain, especially during chewing. He had experienced ten such episodes lasting 10–15 days each in the previous 2 years. Physical examination revealed a swollen left parotid gland with local tenderness and erythema of the overlying skin. The immunological evaluation revealed an IgA level of less than 7 mg/dl. The remaining immunoglobulin IgE, IgM, and IgG were within normal limits. Which of the following is the most important risk about the given condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

questions.correct_answer: D. Anaphylactic reaction on blood transfusion
questions.explanation:
Selective IgA deficiency
  • Most common primary immunodeficiency with low IgA and normal IgG, IgM levels.
  • Patients are susceptible to respiratory and gastrointestinal infections, atopy and anaphylaxis to IgA in blood products.
  • Patients develop IgE antibodies against the IgA antibodies present in transfused blood.
  • This sensitization can result in susceptibility to anaphylaxis on subsequent transfusion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented to the physician's office complaining of low-grade fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and myalgias for the past 3 months. On physical examination, she had oral ulcers and facial rash, as shown in the picture below. Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosing this disease?

  • ↳ Option C: Discoid rash

questions.text: A 42Yr old chronic smoker with a known case of COPD now has complaints of easy fatigability, and shortness of breath has worsened further. On examination, Spo2 is 89%, Dyspneic and tachycardiac. Bronchial Biopsy taken shows stratified squamous cells with underlying glands. Which of the following change is this?

A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 4 hours after the sudden onset of excruciating pain in his right calf . He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The right foot is cold and pale , and palpation of the right posterior tibial artery shows no pulse. Muscle strength is 1/5, and the sensation to touch significantly decreases in the right lower extremity. His serum creatinine kinase concentration is elevated. Arterial duplex sonography shows absent blood flow distal to the right popliteal artery. Compared with a healthy adult, which of the following sets of intracellular electrolyte concentrations are most likely to be found in this patient's right distal gastrocnemius muscle? Na + K + Ca 2+ A ↑ ↓ Normal B ↑ ↑ ↑ C ↓ ↑ Normal D ↓ ↓ Normal E ↑ ↓ ↑

A forty-three-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of a lesion on his left hand. Examination of the dorsal surface of his left-hand shows a scaly erythematous lesion. A skin sample of the lesion shows abnormal keratinocytes covering the entire epidermis thickness. The arrows indicate apoptotic bodies in the image below. In this patient's skin cancer, which of the following proteins plays the most critical role in mediating programmed cell death?

A 33-year-old male presents with a 6-day history of a painful sore on his left hand. Physical examination reveals a 0.6-cm abscess on the extensor surface of the left hand that drains a thick, purulent material. Diapedesis of leukocytes into and around this patient's infected wound occurs primarily at which of the following given anatomic locations ?

An 82-year-old female presents with a 4-hour history of high fever, chills , and disorientation . Her blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals diffuse purpura on her upper arms and chest. Blood cultures are positive for Gram-negative organisms . Which of the following cytokines are involved in the pathogenesis of direct vascular injury with septic shock?

A 67-year-old male presents with persistent complaints of a dry cough for four weeks, which in turn was associated with intermittent fever and easy fatigue . Following a further medical history, he added that he experienced chest discomfort and difficulty breathing during exertion. The vitals examination of the patient reveals SpO2 = 92% in ambient air, heart rate = 110 beats/ min, and respiratory rate = 18 breaths/min. Radiological studies revealed symmetrical hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy , and a black bead cluster sign was observed. On the biopsy, there is a granuloma without a necrotic centre . It is typically seen in which of the following?

A 34-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a high-grade fever and dizziness. Her blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. On examination, she does not have any significant physical findings. She has been using vaginal tampoons for more than 1 month. A diagnosis of toxic shock syndrome is made secondary to the superantigen component of the causative organism. Which of the following is most likely associated with superantigen bacterial product?

options.label: A
options.text: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules

options.label: B
options.text: Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation

options.label: C
options.text: Binds to the CD4 + molecule causing T-cell activation

options.label: D
options.text: Is presented by macrophages to a larger-than-normal number of T helper CD4 + lymphocytes

questions.correct_answer: B. Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation

questions.text: A few Doctors Without Borders physicians on a 6-month African village posting encounter a pale foreigner complaining of extreme fatigue since arrival. He's a diabetic on insulin with controlled bronchial asthma. Despite malaria prophylaxis, he struggles with food adjustment and erratic blood glucose. If suspecting a pharmacogenetic condition, what might explain his current state?

A 24-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain . The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. For further examination of the eyes, the doctor had to pick cycloplegic drops to ensure that the patient did not develop posterior synechiae ; which of the following difference between hyoscine and atropine must the doctor remember well?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye

options.label: D
options.text: Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses

Predisposing Factors - HIV/AIDS- Organ transplantation- Immunosuppressive therapy- Certain malignancies
Clinical Presentation - Dry cough
- Shortness of breath
- Fever
- Chest discomfort
Diagnosis - Chest X-ray or CT scan- Microscopic examination of respiratory specimens- PCR testing

Epidemiology Common among immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS

questions.text: First, add a few crystals of ferrous sulfate to 5 ml of gastric aspirate. Then, add 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide. Boil the mixture and then allow it to cool. Afterward, add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid. If the solution turns a 'greenish-blue color,' this indicates the presence of cyanide in the aspirate. What is the name of this bedside test?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Lee Jones T

Test Purpose and Description Positive Result
Lee Jones Test Purpose: To detect the presence of cyanide in gastric aspirate. Description: A few crystals of ferrous sulfate are added to gastric aspirate, followed by 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide. The mixture is boiled and then cooled, after which 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid are added. A greenish-blue color indicates the presence of cyanide. Greenish-blue color
Marquis Test Purpose: To identify specific drugs or substances in gastric aspirate. Description: The Marquis reagent is used to test for the presence of various drugs, including opioids and amphetamines. The aspirate is mixed with the reagent, and color changes are observed, providing presumptive identification of the substance. Color changes specific to the detected substance.
Marsh Test Purpose: To detect and quantify arsenic in gastric aspirate. Description: The Marsh Test involves the reduction of arsenic compounds to arsine gas (AsH3), which is then detected using various methods, such as flame or graphite furnace atomic absorption spectroscopy. Generation of arsine gas, which can be quantified.
Silver Nitrate Test Purpose: To detect the presence of chloride salts, such as sodium chloride, in gastric aspirate, which may indicate poisoning with toxic substances like mercuric chloride. Description: Silver nitrate solution is added to the aspirate. Formation of a white precipitate (silver chloride) suggests the presence of chloride salts. Formation of white precipitate.
Phenolphthalein Test Purpose: To detect the presence of strong acids or bases in gastric aspirate, which may indicate corrosive substance ingestion. Description: Phenolphthalein solution is added to the aspirate. A color change (pink for bases or colorless for acids) indicates the nature of the substance ingested. Pink or colorless solution.
Dithiothreitol (DTT) Test Purpose: To detect paraquat poisoning in gastric aspirate. Description: DTT is added to the aspirate, and a color change from yellow to colorless or clear indicates the presence of paraquat. Color change from yellow to colorless or clear.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented to the gynecology department with an unwanted pregnancy that she wants to terminate. The physician is giving her Mifepristone. Which of the following is the correct action of this drug for inducing abortion?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Mifepristone (RU 486) in combination with misoprostol is 95% successful in terminating pregnancies of up to 9 week's duration with minimum complications. The commonly used regimen is mifepristone 200 mg orally on day 1, followed by misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally either immediately or within 6- 8 hours. Commercially it comes as an MTP kit having combi pack tablets of mifepristone 200 mg one tablet and misoprostol 200 mcg 4 tablets (800 mcg). The other regimen is a dose of mifepristone 600 mg on day one, followed by 400 mcg orally of misoprostol on day three. The patient should return for a follow-up visit approximately 14 days after the administration of mifepristone to confirm by clinical examination or ultrasonography scan that a complete termination of pregnancy has occurred. Patients who have an ongoing pregnancy at this visit have a risk of fetal malformation resulting from the treatment. Surgical termination is recommended to manage medical abortion treatment failures.
  • ➤ Mifepristone (RU 486) in combination with misoprostol is 95% successful in terminating pregnancies of up to 9 week's duration with minimum complications. The commonly used regimen is mifepristone 200 mg orally on day 1, followed by misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally either immediately or within 6- 8 hours.
  • ➤ Commercially it comes as an MTP kit having combi pack tablets of mifepristone 200 mg one tablet and misoprostol 200 mcg 4 tablets (800 mcg). The other regimen is a dose of mifepristone 600 mg on day one, followed by 400 mcg orally of misoprostol on day three.
  • ➤ The patient should return for a follow-up visit approximately 14 days after the administration of mifepristone to confirm by clinical examination or ultrasonography scan that a complete termination of pregnancy has occurred. Patients who have an ongoing pregnancy at this visit have a risk of fetal malformation resulting from the treatment. Surgical termination is recommended to manage medical abortion treatment failures.

A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib , and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes . What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Accelerated phase of CML

The patient is considered to be in accelerated phase if any of the following are true:

  • The blood samples have 15% or more but fewer than 30% blasts.
  • Basophils make up 20% or more of the blood cells.
  • Blasts and promyelocytes combined makeup 30% or more of the blood.
  • Very low platelet counts (100 x 1,000/cubic meter or less) that are not caused by treatment.
  • New chromosomes changes in the leukaemic cells with the Philadelphia chromosomes

Treatment options are as follows:

  • Patients who present with or evolve to blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • Patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase or patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response).
  • The most effective is stem cell transplantation.

Urine sodium <20 mmol/dl >20 mmol/dl

 

 Variable
FeNa <1 >1 Variable
Urine microscopic findings Hyaline casts Muddy brown casts

 

 Normal or RBC/WBC
BUN: creatinine ratio >20:1 (normal 10:1)

 

 <20:1

 

 >20:1

Prerenal injury: decreased renal blood flow resulting from sepsis, trauma, bleeding, or poor cardiac output

 

 Prolonged low-volume states, such as sepsis, decreased blood pressure, and hemorrhage
  • Such drugs as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents or cyclooxygenase Inhibitors, which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis; in turn, inhibition triggers action of vasoconstrictors on renal arterioles, which decreases glomerular filtration rate.
Intrinsic injury: acute tubular necrosis from sepsis and renal ischemia (mean arterial pressure below 70 mmHg ) and ultimately, from poor organ perfusion and multisystemic failure

 

 Nephropathy caused by contrast agents
  • Aminoglycoside drug therapy without careful dosage monitoring
Postrenal: obstructive nephropathy resulting from mechanical obstruction of urine flow

 

 Renal calculi
  • Tumors
  • Prostatic hypertrophy
  • Strictures
  • Congenital defects

questions.text: A 65 - year - old ma n , CEO of a multinational company, suffered from p alpitations, b reathlessness and s weating while attending a conference. H e was rushed to a nearby hospital. O n physical examination, the patient was pulseless, and his blood pressure was unrecordable. The ECG was done with findings as shown below . Which of the following is the most l ikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Monomorphic VT Polymorphic VT Bidirectional Ventricular fibrillation
Originates from a single focus Originates from multiple foci Two different morphologies of QRS complex Chaotic irregular deflections of varying amplitude
Uniform broad QRS complex Broad QRS complex with varied amplitude, axis and duration Most commonly due to digoxin toxicity P, QRS and T waves are not identifiable
Heart rate 250 beats per minute Heart rate 100-300 beats per minute Rate between 140-180 beats per minute Ventricular rate 150-500 beats per minute

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for 2 weeks . He reports mild substernal chest pain . His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. On examination, he is afebrile, his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, his pulse is 74 beats/min, and his respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min. On chest auscultation, fine basal crackles are heard bilaterally . Heart sounds are normal. Lower limbs are edematous bilaterally up to mid-thigh, and oedema is more pronounced at the ankles . An echocardiogram is done, which reveals an ejection fraction of 25% with anterior, septal, and lateral wall motion defects. He is admitted to the ward and stabilized on furosemide, spironolactone, bisoprolol, and ramipril. What would be the best next investigation in course of his management?
questions.explanation:
Indications of Angiography:
Asymptomatic or Symptomatic Ventricular tachycardia
Symptomatic Acute Coronary Syndrome
Chest pain syndromes
STEMI
Congestive Heart failure
Pericardial disease
Cardiac Transplantation

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to dysuria and passing foamy urine for 2 weeks . He has had a history of type II diabetes mellitus for 20 years, for which he takes insulin irregularly. The recent laboratory investigations reveal: Glucose 200mg/dl Urea 52mg/dl Creatinine 1.2mg/dl Uric acid 5.3mg/dl Blood pressure 160/92mmHg Urine Albumin 35mg The physician suspects a complication of long-standing diabetes mellitus . Which of the following i s associated with this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria

options.label: B
options.text: 24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine

options.label: C
options.text: Microalbuminuria correlates with nocturnal spike in Systolic blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.correct_answer: C. Microalbuminuria correlates with nocturnal spike in Systolic blood pressure

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to his primary health care physician for further evaluation of hypercalcemia detected incidentally during a routine medical check-up. She is asymptomatic and denies constipation, palpitation, or bone pains. Her laboratory investigations are as follows: Haemoglobin 12.2 g/dL Serum Creatinine 0.7 mg/dL Proteins Total 7.0 g/dL Albumin 4.1 g/dL Calcium 13.2 mg/dL Phosphorus 2.2 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase PTH 130 U/L 72 After administration of normal saline, her serum calcium is 12 mg/dl . The rest of the laboratory investigations, including the cancer screen, are normal. What is the most likely indication for surgery in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

questions.correct_answer: D. Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

questions.text: An alcoholic develops intractable vomiting for 2 days with loose motions. Since he had decreased food intake and altered sensorium, he has been brought to the hospital, where the fluid loss and dyselectrolytemia are aggressively corrected with the fluid infusion. Post-treatment, the patient starts having quadriplegia and mutism. What is the most likely diagnosis?

You are an intern posted in a rural PHC. A 26-year-old male presented with complaints of a burning sensation over the chest, usually after eating, associated with regurgitation of food or sore liquid. You prescribed him PPI & advised the patient for follow-up. All of the following statements are true regarding the above condition, except?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs during transient relaxation of LES

options.label: C
options.text: Bicarbonate secreted by oesophageal mucosa neutralizes the acid

options.label: D
options.text: Erosive esophagitis at the esophagogastric junction is the hallmark of GERD

questions.correct_answer: C. Bicarbonate secreted by oesophageal mucosa neutralizes the acid

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented with complaints of 2 episodes of hematemesis. Initial investigations revealed Hb of 7.2g/dl. She was advised to have a UGI endoscopy done. Which of the following finding on upper GI endoscopy indicates the most negligible chances of re-bleeding after hematemesis episodes?

A 63-year-old man presented with a long history of upper abdominal discomfort, anorexia and two episodes of recent gum bleeds without fever or other bleeding manifestations. Examination revealed moderate hepatosplenomegaly . On investigation, he was found to have extreme thrombocytosis and leucocytosis . He was investigated for CML and found to be positive for BCR-ABL by reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR). Vitamin B12 level in this patient would be?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Myelogenous leukaemia
  • Increased levels of
    • Vitamin B12 levels
    • Uric acid levels
    • Serum LDH levels
    • Lysozyme
  • Decreased levels of LAP (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of the right-side face, arm weakness, and difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 76 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences and has difficulty repeating sequences of words . He can follow simple instructions . Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 3/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left . Non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown in the image below. Which is the best step in the management of this patient?

A 29-year-old male presents to the neurology outpatient department, who is a diagnosed case of low-grade astrocytoma , with complaints of recurrent headaches and frequent seizure episodes secondary to his brain tumour. Which of the following anticonvulsant drug is suitable for treating epilepsy in this patient?

A 67-year-old male patient presents to the neurology clinic with weakness in both lower extremities, progressively worsening tingling and numbness, and difficulty getting up from the chair. He has had a history of having laxity in both ankles since his 20s. He also has a tendency for his feet to turn inwards, trip, and subsequently sprain his ankles. Family history also reports having hammertoes in immediate family members involving his mother, sibling, and daughter. On examination, palpable nerves are seen. A typical onion bulb appearance is noted on a biopsy of the nerve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) Disease and Neuropathy
Muscle Appearance - Champagne bottle or stork-leg appearance due to peroneal muscle atrophy
  - Contrasts with pseudo-hypertrophy of calf muscles seen in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
Contractures - Foot contractures due to nerve involvement, leading to walking difficulties
Nerve Thickening - Thickened nerves with onion bulb appearance
Biopsy Findings - Onion bulb appearance also seen in Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
  (a variant of Gullian-Barre Syndrome)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with pre-existing seropositive rheumatoid arthritis presents in the emergency department with complaints of progressive difficulty in breathing. He works as a crane operator near a construction site. On examination, joint findings were consistent with chronic rheumatoid arthritis, and Rheumatoid nodules were appreciated . Hence, a chest X-ray was performed, which is shown below. What is your most likely diagnosis of this patient?

An elderly female patient occupationally teacher presents to the medicine outpatient department. She was complaining of a severe right-sided throbbing headache . Upon history taking, the patient informed that she has a history of polymyalgia rheumatica . The patient also had a history of undocumented weight loss because she had difficulty eating and was constantly fatigue d. On further examination, she also complained of aching of the jaw during chewing . The result of the prescribed lab investigation showed the results of elevated ESR . The symptoms mentioned earlier indicate a vascular disease . Which statement is correct regarding the disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Large vessel vasculitis is commonly seen in patients aged <50 years

options.label: B
options.text: Steroids are contraindicated in this vasculitis

options.label: C
options.text: 50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss

options.label: D
options.text: It is medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis in young adults

questions.correct_answer: C. 50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child was brought with complaints of abdominal distension with a history of intermittent fever, recurrent lung infections, difficulty in walking in the form of repeated falls, difficulty in coordinating movements, an inability to move the eyes vertically, poor muscle tone, severe liver disease, and interstitial lung disease and multiple episodes of tonic-clonic seizures since last 1 year. She also had a younger sibling having similar complaints of abdominal distension and developmental delay. On examination, the patient had hepatosplenomegaly, a global developmental delay with mild mental retardation. A bone marrow examination was done, which showed characteristic lipid-laden foam cells. Lysosomal enzyme studies confirmed the Deficiency of an enzyme. Identify which of the following is responsible for the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Deficient enzyme

Disease

Acid Sphingomyelinase

Niemann pick disease

Hexosaminidase A

Tay-sachs disease

Ceramidase

Farber disease

Arylsulfatase B

Maroteaux – Lamy syndrome

questions.text: A 26-year-old army man presented to our hospital with complaints of breathlessness, mostly on exertion, dry cough and episodes of hemoptysis for the past 18 months. A digital chest radiograph was labelled normal from the outside. Still, on careful observation, bilateral lower lobe infiltration was observed, and then HRCT was advised, which showed early bronchiectatic changes in both lungs. Pulmonary function testing demonstrated a decrease in lung capacity with mild airflow. These characteristic Bronchiectatic features with dry cough are most commonly seen with which of the following?

A 38-year-old female patient who complains of breathlessness on exertion associated with a productive cough has come up for a consult. On auscultation, bilateral basal inspiratory fine crackles. What is the next best step to confirm a diagnosis of ILD?

A 32-year-old female who had nacho cheese the night before presented to the emergency department with complaints of diplopia, followed by dyspnoea, chest tightness, congestion and dysphagia. The patient was resuscitated, and initial investigations were done. The edrophonium tensilon test and lumbar puncture came out to be negative. The botulinum toxin test was positive. The most potent toxin produced in the given condition is?

A 65-year-old woman visited our hospital with her son because she had developed feelings of anxiety and sleep disturbance. She had become unable to cook, make telephone calls, and shop without assistance for two years. She had no history of psychiatric disorders. She was given donepezil 5 mg/day and returned for follow-up visits with her husband around once a month. Feelings of anxiety and sleep disturbance showed improvement at the two-month follow-up visit. Which of the following statements are true in her condition ?

options.label: A
options.text: Onset before 45 years of age is rare

options.label: B
options.text: Long-term memory is affected before short term memory

options.label: C
options.text: Staining shows Tau protein in senile plaques

options.label: D
options.text: MRI shows atrophy in frontal and parietal lobes

questions.correct_answer: A. Onset before 45 years of age is rare
questions.explanation: The last statement can be argued upon. Alzheimer’s disease is usually described as disease of temporal and parietal lobe and MRI usually shows atrophy in temporal and parietal lobe. Although we must remember that frontal cortex does get involved in the advanced phases

questions.text: Sleep disturbances can be caused by a patient's lifestyle. This is commonly referred to as poor sleep hygiene. Universal sleep hygiene focuses on modifiable environmental and lifestyle componentsthat can disrupt sleep, as well as actions that can disrupt sleep Which of the following is not correct advice in this case? which one is not the right advice aboutsleep hygiene?

options.label: A
options.text: Wake up at the same time

options.label: B
options.text: 30 mL and lesser amount of alcohol could be useful to induce sleep over long term

options.label: C
options.text: Use bed for sleep and sexual activity

questions.correct_answer: B. 30 mL and lesser amount of alcohol could be useful to induce sleep over long term

questions.text: An A-30-year old male is brought to the hospital with a history of makingobscene phone conversations withtheunknowncompanion on the telephoneand vocally discloses his preoccupations or entices her to discuss her sexual activities. Masturbation generally follows the talk, which is often finished after the contact is broken. He is diagnosed as having Scatology, which is an example of?

A 6-year-old male presents to the clinic by her mother with the complaint of poor speech development. On examination, the child has difficulty concentrating and communicating and has poor speech development. His mother also reports that he has no friends and spends most of the day looking at his own hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
Which of the following is an indication for adjuvant chemotherapy after mastectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy

options.label: D
options.text: There is no indication for adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented to the casualty complaining of swelling in the right side of the neck region . After reading some information online, he is worried that he has anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. A small, solitary nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid was noted on physical examination, and FNAC reveals follicular adenoma . Which of the following is the best surgery for this condition ?
Which of the following characteristics is not seen in a patient of Grave's disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Subperiosteal new bone formation in metacarpals

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought in with complaints of abdominal mass, blueberry muffin spots on the skin, proptosis, and periorbital ecchymosis. Upon further evaluation, urinary catecholamines and their metabolites were elevated . Which of the following is incorrect about the described condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood

options.label: D
options.text: It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain

questions.correct_answer: B. Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood

questions.text: A 37-year-old female was admitted with a complaint of escalating abdominal pain, increased abdominal circumference, and recurrent diarrhea for 2 months. He has a history of consumption of bush teas for 5 months to reduce weight. Physical examination revealed mild jaundice, distended abdomen, and tenderness on RUQ. Laboratory results showed WBC 6.82 × 10 9 /L, Hb 122 g/L, HbsAg (-), ALT 66 U/L, AST 81 U/L, serum total bilirubin 39.7 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 10.6 μmol/L, and ALB 32.8 g/L. CT scan of the abdomen revealed moderate ascites, hepatomegaly, delayed enhancement of parenchyma, and obscure hepatic veins . Which of the following drugs is effective in improving survival in this patient?

A 46-year-old woman was admitted for appetite loss, nausea, and back p ain . A physical examination revealed right hypochondriac tenderness and obvious jaundice . MRCP revealed dilated intrahepatic and common hepatic bile ducts, distended gallbladder, and erosion of less than 1/3 of the circumference of common hepatic duct. What is the best next step in the management?
questions.explanation:
I Extrinsic compression of the common bile duct by an impacted gallstone
II Cholecystobiliary fistula secondary to an eroded gallstone involving one third of the circumference of the common bile duct
III Cholecystobiliary fistula involving two thirds of the circumference of the common bile duct
IV Cholecystobiliary fistula comprising the whole circumference of the common bile duct
V Any type plus a cholecystoenteric fistula
Va Without gallstone ileus
Vb With gallstone ileus

Types Treatment
Type I Partial cholecystectomy
Type II & III Partial cholecystectomy + T- tube drainage
Type IV & V Partial cholecystectomy + Bilioenteric anastomosis

questions.text: Which of the following is risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Fair skin(skin type I and II)

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented to us with c/o epigastric pain and weight loss. He also gave a history of dyspepsia and progressively increasing jaundice with clay-colored stools with no history of fever or pruritus. On physical examination, there was evidence for icterus without any palpable neck lymphadenopathy. Abdominal and chest CT scan confirmed the presence of a tumor measuring 50 mm in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) also indicated that the tumor was in contact with both the SMA and the SMV, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. On the basis of these clinical findings, the patient was diagnosed with Unresectable Locally Advanced Pancreatic cancer. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to the patient to increase his survival rate?
Where is Killian's dehiscence located ?

options.label: D
options.text: Below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the surgical OPD with an epigastric mass, early satiety, and weight loss for the last 3 months. Abdominal examination revealed an irregular mass in the epigastric region 4×5cm, moving with respiration, and hard in consistency . Endoscopic Biopsy from an ulcer-proliferative lesion in the greater curvature revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is a manifestation of carcinoma stomach?

A 70-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with colicky pain in the lower abdomen. He also complains of absolute constipation. After performing a physical examination, an X-ray is ordered. The abdominal X-ray findings are given below: Which of the following is the preferred treatment option for this patient?

A 29-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient department with complaints of mucus -containing diarrhea and bleeding per rectum from the last 3 months. On presentation patient's vitals are blood pressure of 90/70 mmHg, pulse rate of 110 beats/min, and respiratory rate of 21/min. On further evaluation, colonoscopy findings are consistent with ulcerative colitis . The patient does not respond to medical therapy. What will be the treatment of choice in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Colectomy + manual proctectomy + ileoanal pouch anastomosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Proctocolectomy with ileoanal pouch anastomosis

questions.text: A 7-year-old with a history of bed wetting and recurrent urinary tract infections is brought with complaints of left-sided abdominal pain that intensifies on urination. She has a fever of 101 F°. Left costovertebral angle tenderness is present. IV pyelogram is conducted, and urinary tract infection is suspected. How would this condition be treated?

options.label: A
options.text: If the function of the upper pole ureter is normal, then no intervention is needed, and for the lower pole ureter, ureterovesicoplasty can be done

options.label: B
options.text: Both the poles should be excised and reimplanted into the bladder as the patient may become susceptible to UTI more frequently

options.label: C
options.text: For upper pole hydronephrosis with no function, an Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed.

options.label: D
options.text: The lower pole ureter is prone to develop Ureterocele, so it should be excised in any case

questions.correct_answer: C. For upper pole hydronephrosis with no function, an Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presented to the local hospital with complaints of urinary retention with severe pain and burning sensation in the lower urinary tract since yesterday. He also has a poor urinary stream, nocturia, and post-void dribbling. The vital signs and Laboratory tests were normal. On digital rectal examination, there is a palpable, hard, nodular prostate with an obliterated median sulcus. Ultrasound reports showed an enlarged prostate of weight 93 grams. His ratio of free: total PSA is estimated as 20%. The ultrasound of this patient is given below. What diagnosis does the doctor suspect in this case?

A 26-year-old woman has been experiencing lower abdominal pain and frequent urination for seven months. She has no other symptoms, and tests have been inconclusive. Cystoscopy revealed a finding, what is true about the management of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Conservative management; Has a good prognosis

options.label: B
options.text: Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder

questions.correct_answer: B. Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder

questions.text: During Orchiopexy for undescended testes, accidental ligation of which artery compromises the blood supply to the testes?

A 43-year-old male race-course farrier presents to his family doctor complaining of persistent pain and numbness, fatigue, and frequent cramps extending bilaterally throughout the upper limbs (especially on the right side). Colour flow Doppler USG is prescribed, which reveals bilateral functional stenosis of the axillary-subclavian vein, which is more severe on the right side. A subsequent angiography-assisted CT scan shows the presence of right subclavian venous thrombosis. What is likely the management plan for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: IV anticoagulants + Rest should be advised as the provocative factor is his occupation

options.label: C
options.text: Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with the complaint of progressively worsening ulcers in the fingertips of both hands and feet for 4 years, along with intermittent claudication of the feet whenever he is walking. After taking history, he told the doctor that he had "migratory superficial thrombophlebitis." He is a 20-pack-year smoker who is not a diabetic; his cholesterol levels are normal according to him, and his ECG findings were normal. What would be the best way for this patient to arrest the development of his disease?

A 52-year-old female smoker presented with non-small cell lung cancer from the lateral segmental right middle lobar orifice. Preoperative evaluation revealed excellent pulmonary reserve and no evidence of metastatic disease. Mediastinoscopy had negative results . A right vertical axillary thoracotomy revealed a central 3.0 cm adenocarcinoma invading the superior pulmonary vein and the descending pulmonary artery . Hence, the patient was prepared for pneumonectomy . What is the first step when doing a pneumonectomy in this patient?

A 50-year-old male presents to the physician because of a skin lesion on his nose. The lesion has gradually increased since it first appeared 11 months ago . He is a farmer and lives together with his wife. Examination of the skin shows a nontender lesion at the right medial canthus. An image of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old female presented with squamous cell carcinoma of her lower lip . The lesion involved the full lower lip and partly skin of the chin. Under general anesthesia, an extended peripheral resection is done. Then, modified extended Karapandzic flaps were used to rebuild the lower lip and tongue mucosa flap to rebuild the vermilion. Which of the following is the most likely advantageous point of the Karapandzic flap ?

options.label: C
options.text: It is a neuromuscular preserving flap

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a neuromuscular preserving flap
questions.explanation:
Cross-lip Flaps Circumoral Advancement Flaps
Lip-Switch (Abbe-Estlander) flap used to repair defects of either the upper or lower lip, based on the superior labial artery
  • Karapandzic flap: Uses a sensate, neuromuscular flap Uses a sensate, neuromuscular flap based on the labial artery.
  • Webster-Bernard repair: Use lateral nasolabial flap with buccal advancement

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the clinic with insidious onset of deep, dull aching pain in the left hand involving distal interphalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and 1st carpometacarpal joints are worsened by activity and improved by rest. The patient also complains of joint stiffness in the morning, lasting less than 30 minutes. There is a sparing of meta-Carpo-phalangeal and wrist joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Rheumatoid Arthritis Osteoarthritis
Synovitis Arthritis
Osteopenia Sclerosis (below the joint)
Genu Valgum Genu varum

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a crush injury of the lower limb 30 minutes ago . The patient is in severe pain. Limbs appear mottled on the examination. questions.text: A 30-year-old female comes to the hospital to evaluate a finger deformity. She started experiencing pain and difficulty using her fingers a few weeks ago. She has a long history of rheumatoid arthritis but does not take medicines regularly. Which of the following is correct about the given deformity?

A 65-year-old male is brought to the orthopedic emergency department after a fall from a height while working on a high roof. The patient is in severe pain. There is tenderness on the greater trochanter, and the patient cannot walk. The lateral border of the foot touches the bed. The senior resident is expecting some fracture of a bone on the lower leg. He orders an X-ray to confirm. What is the most common complication in the affected area in the given clinical scenario?
questions.explanation:
Fracture of Neck of Femur Inter Trochanteric Fracture
Intracapsular Extracapsular
Less Common More Common
60 years 80 years
External rotation < 45o as extracapsular; the capsule impedes full external rotation after Fracture

Increased pain

questions.text: The rationale for adding dextrose in spinal anaesthesia is to:

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce plasma levels of local anesthetic to prevent toxicity

questions.text: A 45-year-old perimenopausal woman was admitted with a history of abnormal uterine bleeding for the past 6 months. She was posted for a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salphingo oophorectomy. The anaesthesia plan was spinal anaesthesia with an epidural catheter for postoperative analgesia. Postoperative pain scores were low, and the patient was comfortable postoperatively. The epidural catheter was removed after 48 hours. What is the most appropriate indication for this type of anaesthesia?

A 45-year-old female is being posted for a right-modified radical mastectomy under general anaesthesia. Induction of anaesthesia is done with Inj. Propofol and endotracheal intubation is facilitated with Inj. Atracurium. While doing mask ventilation after administering muscle relaxant, the monitor showed a blood pressure reading of 75/40 mmHg, a pulse rate to be 130/minute, and flushing of the face, which was treated with intravenous fluid bolus and Inj. Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV. Which of the following is the underlying mechanism of these observed findings?

options.label: B
options.text: Effects mediated by autonomic nicotinic cholinergic receptors

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced peripheral vascular resistance by propofol

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intestinal obstruction has been admitted to the surgical ward. The conservative treatment does not relieve his symptoms. He has been taken for immediate surgery. The anaesthesia with inhaled anaesthetic has been started. Which of the following factor decreases the MAC of the inhaled anaesthetic?
questions.explanation:
PHYSIOLOGIC & PHARMACOLOGIC FACTORS AFFECTING MAC
Increase in MAC
  • Hyperthermia
  • Hypernatraemia
  • Drug induced elevation of CNS catecholamine stores
  • Chronic alcohol abuse & chronic opioid abuse
  • Increases in ambient pressure (experimental)
  • Cyclosporine
  • Excess pheomelanin production (red hair)

 

 

 

 

 Decrease in MAC
  • Hypothermia & Hyperthermia (if >42 C)
  • Hyponatraemia
  • Drug induced decrease in CNS cate cholamine level
  • Increasing age (6% decrease/decade)
  • Preoperative medication
  • Hypoxemia (PAO2 <38mm Hg)
  • Hypotension(<40 mm hg-MAP)
  • Anemia (Hematocrit <10%)
  • Pregnancy ( progesterone)
  • Postpartum(returns to normal in 24-72 hours)
  • CNS depressant drugs Opioids, Benzodiazepines TCA's etc.
  • Other drugs-lithium, Lidocaine, Magnesium
  • Acute alcohol abuse
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass

questions.text: A 22-year-old boxer was brought to the Emergency departmen t by an ambulance. He had a boxing match prior to his arrival. The attending physician did a thorough physical checkup and suspected an orbital floor fracture . He immediately ordered an X-ray of the orbital floor. What is the most appropriate view of X-ray for this patient?
Which is not a finding of endometriosis :
questions.explanation:
Type

Characteristics

I

Direct fistulae to the pouch (median prosencephalic vein).

II

Indirect arteriolovenous fistulae through an intervening tangle of vessels (nidus) between the arteries and the vein.

III

Combination of Types I and II: mixture of direct arteriovenous and arteriolovenous fistulae.

questions.text: A patient with suspected case of tuberculoma was sent to radiological department for brain imaging . The radiologist decided to take MR spectroscopy . Which peak on MR spectroscopy is seen in tuberculoma?

A 37 yr old man was referred to NIMHANS Neurology opd with a history of 2 episodes of GTCS, Headache, weakness on the right side of the body, behavior , and personality changes. NCCT is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis that can be made?

A 38-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of failure to conceive. She has been married for 10 years and has a baby of 8 years. She is undergoing infertility evaluation for secondary infertility. Her past pregnancy was spontaneously conceived 8 years back. A few blood tests evaluate ovarian reserve, including inhibin B, considering her age. Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at which stage of the menstrual cycle.

A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic, reporting that she is late for her period by one day. She has been married for 4 years and has 2 children. She has no significant gynecological history. She has had regular periods. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. She is advised to wait for another few days and gets her period the next day. options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. The involution of the corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient who is being treated for infertility gets ovulation induction with clomiphene and Inj. hCG. questions.text: A 40-year-old female with abnormal menstrual bleeding and a pelvic mass undergoes a hysterectomy. The image shows the gross specimen removed. What is the diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl presents in the outpatient clinic with the complaint of primary amenorrhea. She has short stature; on the examination, there is no breast development. Ultrasound reveals a hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries. The doctor ordered hormonal assays, which showed high levels of FSH. Karyotyping is suggested to confirm the suspected condition, which is XO. What is the probable cause of this condition?

A 37-year-old female presents to the gynaecology clinic for counselling regarding contraception. She desires to start COCPs. She is a well-controlled diabetic patient. She smokes one pack (of 20) of cigarettes daily. She is also hypertensive, and her blood pressure is 140/90 on drugs and known case of Arterial thrombosis. Total serum cholesterol is 275 mg/dL. COCPs are contraindicated in her more strongly due to which of the following factors in her history?

A 34-year-old woman who has been using IUCD for contraception for a year now presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, fever and pain in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response, and then decide on IUCD removal.

options.label: B
options.text: Start antibiotics and then remove IUCD

options.label: C
options.text: Remove IUCD and then start antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Wait till the next menstrual cycle for any intervention

questions.correct_answer: A. Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response, and then decide on IUCD removal.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, G1P0, at 24 weeks of pregnancy, presents to the outpatient department for a routine prenatal visit. The pregnancy was planned. She takes no medications except folic acid and iron tablets. On examination, S2 and S3 are easily audible, and a systolic ejection murmur is greater during inspiration. Which of the following is true regarding these findings in the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of S3 is abnormal

options.label: B
options.text: The systolic ejection murmur is unusual in a pregnant woman at term

options.label: C
options.text: Wide pulse pressure is rare in pregnant women

options.label: D
options.text: All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 30 weeks gestation with nausea and dizziness every time she lies down. She states that the symptoms subside when she turns on her side. Which of the following is the best explanation of such a presentation?
questions.explanation:
Supine hypotension syndrome
  • Nausea and dizziness in a pregnant female on lying down are due to IVC compression, which resolves if patient lies on her side as the compression is removed.
  • The gravid uterus compresses the IVC, thus reduces the venous return leading to supine hypotension syndrome.

Advantages of Left Lateral Position:

  • Improves uteroplacental circulation
  • Increase Fetal Oxygen saturation

questions.text: A 32-year-old female comes for an antenatal check-up. She is 7 weeks pregnant and had a missed abortion 2 years ago. She is really worried and wants to know the well-being of the fetus. Which of the following is the best modality to detect fetal cardiac activity?
questions.explanation:
Sac Cardiac activity
TVS 4+ weeks 5+ weeks
TAS 5+ weeks 6+ weeks

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks of gestation, presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her routine antenatal evaluation. questions.explanation:
Sutures and methods to secure hemostasis

Description

Cho suture

  1. A compression suture
  2. Also known as multiple square suture
  3. 4-5 square sutures are sued for the atonic uterus

Hayman suture

  1. A compression suture
  2. Transfixes the entire uterine wall
  3. Two longitudinal threads are used

B-lynch suture

 
  1. Two sutures are applied ongitudinally which gives brace suspender appearance
  2. Also known as Brace suture

questions.text: A primigravida is shifted f or delivery in the second stage of labour. questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic primigravida, at 36 weeks of gestation, comes to the obstetric department for a routine antenatal check-up. She is completely well, and her pregnancy was uneventful except for a history of fewer fetal activities 2 days ago. Her diabetes is well-controlled, and she takes the multivitamins, iron, and calcium pills as prescribed. Upon physical examination, her vitals were normal, and the physician ordered an NST (Non-Stress test) to assess fetal well-being. The patient may be sent back home and asked to return after 1 week if the NST shows any of the following findings:

options.label: A
options.text: At least two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5-25 bpm

options.label: B
options.text: One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5- 25 bpm

options.label: C
options.text: Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

options.label: D
options.text: Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, G3P2 at the gestation of 12 weeks has come to the hospital. She also has a history of preterm births at 30 and 32 weeks during her last 2 pregnancies. Which of the following would be the next step in managing this patient?

A 12-year-old girl is accompanied to the obstetrics and gynecology OPD by her mother . The girl has not yet started menstruation. options.label: D

questions.text: An 8-day-old male neonate is brought to the emergency department by his mother with complaints of fever and poor feeding for the past 8 hours. Her mother has a history of premature membrane ruptures leading to an emergency cesarean section. The child has no other abnormalities. On examination, the neonate has a temperature of 104°F, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and chest pain. options.label: B

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia delivers a baby at 32 weeks of gestation. She was given magnesium sulfate . As the delivery is prolonged and the umbilical cord becomes wrapped around the baby's neck, it leads to perinatal asphyxia ; his APGAR score is calculated and shifted to the NICU. options.label: A

options.label: C

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with growth retardation associated with intellectual disability. Further history revealed that the patient had delayed milestone development. Further examination revealed kinky hair . Lab investigations revealed low serum copper levels . What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 30-month-old deaf boy whose development is slower than normal is being followed for congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in your clinic. The child's mother is pregnant again and is worried about her new baby. Which of the followin g is advisory information to be given to the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The mother has antibodies to CMV that is passed to the fetus

options.label: B
options.text: The mother’s infection cannot become reactivated

options.label: D
options.text: The new infant should be isolated from the older child

questions.correct_answer: A. The mother has antibodies to CMV that is passed to the fetus
questions.explanation:
Congenital CMV
  • CMV is the most common cause of congenital infections
  • In primary CMV infection in the first trimester of pregnancy, most of these babies die, and those who survive are severely affected
  • However, most in secondary maternal infection infants infected are asymptomatic and 10% of them eventually manifest hearing and neurologic problems because maternal IgG antibodies pass transplacentally and protect the baby against infection
  • Some authorities recommend keeping a child with congenital CMV infection away from susceptible pregnant women because CMV excretion can persist for months to years

When the mother gave one biscuit in her baby's hand, to her surprise, the child could take the biscuit to her mouth all by herself. At what age can the child do that ?

A 70-year-old Chinese male presents to the clinic due to right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy for 4 months. It is associated with 3 episodes of epistaxis . On physical examination , unilateral serous otitis media, ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia, and ipsilateral palatal palsy are seen additionally. The patient is a suspected case of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma. Which of the following is the best prognostic factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.?
questions.explanation:
WHO type PATHOLOGY Risk factor Other factors Survival/ Recurrence
I 25% Keratinizing Squamous cell differentiated carcinoma Smoking Low-risk population Older age Non-familial factors 10% Survival
II 12% Non-keratinizing Squamous cell differentiated carcinoma EBV Preserved foods Familial factors 50% Survival
III 60% Non-keratinizing Squamous cell undifferentiated carcinoma EBV High a risk population, Children Preserved foods Familial factors 60% Survival Best prognosis

Tumour/Node/Metastasis Staging of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
Stage Description
T Classification
Tx Primary tumours cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of a tumour
T1 Confined to the nasopharynx or extends to the oropharynx and/or nasal cavity
T2 The tumour extends to the parapharyngeal space
T3 Tumour involves sinuses and/or the skull base
T4 Intracranial, infratemporal/masticator space involvement, cranial nerve involvement, orbit, or hypopharynx
N Classification
N0 No nodal involvement
N1 Unilateral cervical lymph nodes ≤6cm, or unilateral or bilateral retropharyngeal nodes ≤6 cm above the supraclavicular fossa
N2 Bilateral cervical lymph nodes ≤6 cm above supraclavicular fossa
N3a Lymph node >6 cm
N3b Supraclavicular lymph node
M Classification
M0 No distant metastasis
M1 Distant metastasis (includes mediastinal nodes)
Stage Classification
Stage I T1N0M0
Stage II T1N1M0, T2N0M0 and T2N1M0
Stage III T3N0M0, T3N1M0, and T1 to T3N2M0
Stage Iva T4, any NM0
Stage IVb Any TN3M0
Stage IV Any T; any N, M1

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings: Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Most commonly caused by Staphylococcus proteins. Can present with ocular pain and photophobia. Some people complain of foreign body sensations. The t reatment is steroids.
  • ➤ Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought by his parents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of ocular misalignment and also explains that when the child focuses on an object, his eyes are crossed . options.label: A
options.text: Refraction under atropine followed by full correction

questions.correct_answer: A. Refraction under atropine followed by full correction

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with a known case of diabetes mellitus for 9 years presented with complaints of sudden drooping of his left eyelid and double vision in the left eye. On examination, the pupil of the left eye had a sluggish reaction to direct light and measured 6 mm, compared with 3 mm in the right eye with a normal reaction to light. The cover test revealed that the patient could not adduct, supraduct, or infraduct, his left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman came to the Medical outpatient department complaining of blurry vision; on inquiring, she told me she had been a patient of diabetes for 10 years. Moreover, have uncontrollable Blood pressure and kidney disease. She told the doctor that she had been diagnosed with proliferative diabetic retinopathy a few months ago. Now she complains of floaters and painless loss of vision. The doctor thinks of retinal detachment. Which type of retinal detachment is most commonly seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy?

A 30-year-old young m ale came with sudden onset visual loss with no history of trauma. The fundus details cannot be appreciated on fundoscopy, and there is no significant systemic history. The other eye has evidence of sheathing of vessels in the periphery. Regarding the above-given condition, which one is the most common presenting symptom of this disease?

A 12-year-old girl presents with a yellowish "birthmark" on the scalp. Her mother reports that the lesion has progressively become thicker and warty. She is asymptomatic, but they are concerned regarding the cosmetic appearance. Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A 63-year-old male presents with a lesion on his toe that has doubled in size in the past year. It is non-tender and does not bleed, but his wife says it’s getting bigger and darker on one side. On examination, the macule is 7mm in diameter. Which of the following is the best next step?

A 63-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic with a history of chronic leg swelling for several years. She reports that her legs get intermittently red and swollen. When this happens, she applies a combination of lanolin and Neosporin. She further explains that one week ago, she applied the same drug combination, and her legs got inflamed, and she developed blisters, oozing, and severe pruritus within a few minutes. Which of the following condition has likely caused her skin symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Allergic contact dermatitis Allergic contact dermatitis is caused by a variety of agents. Acutely patient presents with itching, blistering, oozing, and other signs of inflammation.
Bullous Impetigo

 

 Begins with small vesicles that become flaccid bullae which contain a clear or yellow fluid THAT eventually progresses to become purulent or dark. Surrounding erythema and edema are typically absent.
Cellulitis Poorly demarcated, a warm, erythematous area with associated edema and tenderness to palpation.
Erysipelas Area of skin erythema that is sharply demarcated with raised edges with complaints of burning, tenderness, and itchiness at the site.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female visits the clinic with a complaint of fever, painful swelling of the vulva, and dysuria for the last three days. On examination, multiple red vesicles are found on the genital area. There is a history of new sexual contact seven days back. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
